docs.lead_paragraph: Federal investigators hunting for Martin R. Frankel, the Connecticut money manager wanted in a huge insurance fraud, say they believe that they have traced him to Europe and are actively pursuing leads there, Government law enforcement officials said yesterday. Details of the hunt for Mr. Frankel were among several revelations yesterday, as a Connecticut criminal lawyer disclosed that he had been authorized to represent the financier, and Mississippi regulators said that they had filed orders to liquidate three insurance companies in Mr. Frankel's crumbling corporate empire.

headline.main: Clues in Search For Financier Lead to Europe

docs.abstract: Federal investigators hunting for Martin R Frankel, Connecticut money manger wanted in huge insurance fraud, say they believe that they have traced him to Europe and are actively pursuing leads there; details of hunt for Frankel are among several revelations, as Connecticut criminal lawyer Hugh F Keefe discloses that he has been authorized to represent Frankel, and Mississippi regulators say they have filed orders to liquidate three insurance companies in Frankel's crumbling corporate empire; Keefe agrees tentatively to represent Frankel; says he has not met with Frankel in person, and does not know how Frankel obtained his name; Mississippi regulators liquidate Franklin Protective Life Insurance Co and Family Guaranty Life Insurance Co, both units of Franklin American Corp, and First National Life Insurance Co of America, subsidiary of International Financial Corp; total liabilities of three companies put at $21.8 million (M)
docs.snippet: Federal investigators hunting for Martin R. Frankel, the Connecticut money manager wanted in a huge insurance fraud, say they believe that they have traced him to Europe and are actively pursuing leads there, Government law enforcement officials said...

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: FIRST NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO OF AMERICA

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Many Dentists Won't Fix Poor Children's Bad Teeth'' (news article, June 26): Children with chronic illnesses or disabilities also experience difficulty in getting needed oral health care, which increases their health risks. Although dental decay is the most common infectious disease of childhood, treatment is not deemed medically necessary by most health insurance plans.
docs.abstract: Dr Wendy E Mouradian letter deplores refusal of many dentists to fix teeth of poor children (June 26 article)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Many Dentists Won't Fix Poor Children's Bad Teeth'' (news article, June 26): Children with chronic illnesses or disabilities also experience difficulty in getting needed oral health care, which increases their health risks....
